awd_abstract_narration: This research deals with the theory of rubber elasticity, a                property that is unique to polymers.  Specifically, it deals with               the role of topological constraints, in the form of molecular-                  chain entanglements, on the mechanical properties of crosslinked                rubber networks.  In one approach, the equilibrium entanglements                will be modeled in a mean-field manner, by subjecting all of the                segments of each network chain to some type of confinement that                 is transverse to the direction of the chain.  This is the so-                   called "tube model."  In another approach, nonequilibrium                       entanglement effects will be modeled in terms of a process                      involving multiple barriers represented by the discrete                         entanglements along the contour of dangling chains and unattached               chains.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
